events.title: Birth of Wolfgang Ketterle
events.description: Wolfgang Ketterle was born in Heidelberg, Germany

events.title: W.K. Realisation on his career path
events.description: At 32, W.K. realised his interest in basic research and identified the field of cold atoms as a promising area.

events.title: Family moved to Eppelheim
events.description: When Wolfgang Ketterle was three, his family moved from Heidelberg to Eppelheim

events.title: Family Picture
events.description: Wolfgang Ketterle had a family picture with his parents and siblings

events.title: Entered University of Heidelberg
events.description: In 1976, W.K. entered the University of Heidelberg, located in his home town.

events.title: Received Fellowship from Studienstiftung des Deutschen Volkes
events.description: Before starting university, W.K. received a fellowship from Studienstiftung des Deutschen Volkes (German National Merit Foundation).

events.title: Photo with family
events.description: A photo of W.K. (second from left) with his parents and siblings was taken.

events.title: Started Ph.D. Research
events.description: In July 1983, during the first year of his Ph.D. research, W.K. is sitting in front of the racks controlling an ion beam of triatomic hydrogen.

events.title: Marriage of W.K. and Gabriele Sauer
events.description: W.K. marries Gabriele Sauer, whom he had known since high school.

events.title: Birth of Jonas
events.description: W.K. and Gabriele Sauer had their first child, Jonas.

events.title: Defended Ph.D. Thesis
events.description: W.K. defended his Ph.D. thesis on the subject of trace analysis of semiconductors using laser spectroscopy.
actors: Max Planck Institute for Quantum Optics

events.title: Postdoc at the Max-Planck Institute for Quantum Optics
events.description: After earning his Ph.D., the author stayed at the Max-Planck Institute as a postdoc, working on laser excitation of Rydberg states of triatomic hydrogen and helium hydride. He also succeeded in analyzing all the emission spectra of helium hydride, which he had discovered during his Ph.D.

events.title: Transition to Applied Research
events.description: The author decided to pursue applied research in a university setting, maintaining at least some of the freedom of academic research. He joined the group of Prof. Jürgen Wolfrum at the University of Heidelberg. There, he worked in physical chemistry, focusing on combustion diagnostics with lasers. Molecular spectroscopy, in which he was an expert by this time, was used to measure temperature and molecular concentrations in a flame.

events.title: Collaboration with Volkswagen
events.description: One of his main projects was carried out in collaboration with the Volkswagen company. They had to transport a truckload of lasers and equipment to an engine test stand at the plant and encountered problems such as soot on the windows of the transparent engine and optics dripping with oil coming from a Diesel engine.

events.title: Birth of Johanna
events.description: W.K. and Gabriele Sauer had their second child, Johanna.

events.title: W.K. joins Dave Pritchard’s group at MIT
events.description: In the spring of 1990, W.K. joined Dave Pritchard’s group at MIT. During the first year at MIT, he was supported by a fellowship of DAAD (Deutscher Akademischer Auslandsdienst).

events.title: Birth of Holger
events.description: W.K. and Gabriele Sauer had their third child, Holger.

events.title: Separation of W.K. and Gabriele Sauer
events.description: W.K. and Gabriele Sauer separated two months before it was announced that W.K. was awarded the Nobel prize.
